ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Visit name
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2, Daily

ElementDescription: Form used/assessment name
Notes: e.g., Self-Report, Parent Form, Short Form, Revised Version

ElementDescription: Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data
I cannot treat psychosocial problems.
My patients do not want me to investigate psychosocial problems.
I cannot help patients with problems I have not experienced myself.
I do not focus on psychosocial problems until I have ruled out organic disease.
If I address psychosocial issues, patients will reject them and never return.
Mind and brain influence physical disease and body perception.
Exploring psychological issues with the patient often causes me pain.
The biological model of disease is the most appropriate model for health care.
I am intruding when I ask psychosocial questions.
I must consider organic and psychosocial problems concurrently.
It is difficult to deal with psychosocial problems when I have many of the same problems as my patients.
Evaluating and treating psychosocial problems will cause me to be more overburdened than I already am.
I feel guilty probing the psychological concerns of my patients.
I am too pressed for time to routinely investigate psychosocial issues.
My patients feel questions about the psychosocial aspects of their lives are irrelevant.
The stresses we all experience do not significantly influence the onset or course of disease.
One reason I do not consider psychosocial information is the limited time I have available.
Patient will become more dependent on me if I open up psychosocial concerns.
If I deal with psychosocial issues, I will lose patients.
There are so many issues to be investigated when seeing a patient that I do not always consider psychosocial factors.
My own psychological problems do not interfere with my ability to treat patients.
Consideration of psychosocial problems will require more effort than I have to give.
Patients blame me for psychological problems.
Talking about psychosocial issues causes more trouble than it is worth.
Investigating psychosocial issues decreases my efficiency,
Patients will reject the idea of my dealing with psychosocial issues.
Investigating psychosocial issues causes me to lose time and money.
I can't help a patient with a psychosocial problem that I have not resolved for myself.
I can investigate psychosocial issues without decreasing my efficiency.
I focus on organic disease because I cannot treat the psychosocial.
Depressed patients frequently present with vegetative somatic complaints.
Patients with psychosocial concerns tend to become dependent on me.
My patients and/or their caregivers do not want me to investigate psychosocial problems.
I cannot help patients with problems I have not experienced myself.
I focus on physical health because I cannot treat psychosocial problems.
If I address psychosocial issues, patients will reject these issues and never return.
I feel guilty probing the psychosocial concerns of my patients.
I find great satisfaction in treating psychosocial problems in my patients.
Evaluating/treating psychosocial problems will cause me to be overburdened.
I cannot help a patient with a psychosocial problem I have not resolved myself.
The psychosocial problems we all experience do not significantly influence the onset or course of disease.
One reason I do not consider information about psychosocial problems is the limited time I have available.
Exploring psychosocial issues with patients often causes me pain.
There are so many factors to be investigated when seeing patients that I do not always consider psychosocial issues.
Patients will become more dependent on me if I raise psychosocial concerns.
Investigating issues of psychosocial problems decreases my efficiency.
Total score (sum all 14 items pbs_a through pbs_n)
Beliefs and feelings score (original score: sum items a,b,c,d,e,f,h,i)
Beliefs and feelings score (re-scored; sum items a,b,c,d,e,f-rev,h,i)
Burden score (sum items g,j,k,l,m,n)
Total score (sum pbs_1 through pbs_32)
